text.p: The European Parliament approved on Tuesday an accord reached with the Council on October 10 on the Customs 2000 multiannual action programme.
The 50-million-Ecu programme is designed to make customs controls at the European Union's external borders more efficient and more consistent.
By creating standard practices at all external border controls, the programme should improve the functioning of the internal market.

Under the deal worked out between Council and Parliament in October, the member states commit themselves to computerising their customs services, as a means of combatting fraud, and improve training for customs officers.
The compromise also provides for more exchanges of information and personnel and allows customs officials to wear the EU 12-star symbol on their uniforms.
Rapporteur Karl von Wogau (German Christian Democrat) insisted the EU symbol was a significant way of reinforcing the idea of a single EU "home market".
